name: starting succeeding and failing in business

children.name: to start a new business or organization
start b2
children.definition: start/ to start a new business or organization:
examples: ▪ john decided to start his own textile business shortly after the war.
start up
▪ luigi’s family came here in 1966 and started up a chain of restaurants.

children.name: open b2
children.definition: open/ˈəʊpən/  to start a business that provides services to the public, such as a shop, restaurant, or hotel:
examples: ▪ they just opened a new supermarket on van nuys boulevard.
▪ the rail company plans to open several new lines over the next five years.

children.name: set up x
children.definition: set up/ˌset ˈʌp/  to start a new business by making all the necessary arrangements, buying equipment etc:
examples: ▪ kate and her partner are setting up their own printing business.
set up in businessto start to run your own business
▪ the enterprise center runs courses for people who want to set up in business on their own.
set up as
▪ dad set up as a builder in 1990 and now he employs over twenty men.

children.name: establish b2
children.definition: establish/ɪˈstæblɪʃ/  to start an important organization that is intended to be permanent, or that continues for a very long time:
examples: ▪ the company was established in 1899.
▪ most of the money will be used to establish local industries and mobilize the work-force.
establishment[uncountable noun]
▪ the establishment of nato in 1949 gave the us a leading role in the defence of europe.

children.name: found b2
children.definition: found/faʊnd/  to start an organization, school, hospital etc, especially by providing the money for it - use this especially about something that was started a long time ago:
examples: ▪ who originally founded the college?
▪ the bank was founded 60 years ago in munich.
foundation/faʊnˈdeɪʃən/ [uncountable noun] c1
▪ the hospital has served the needs of the local community since its foundation in 1863.

children.name: inception x
children.definition: inception/ɪnˈsepʃən/  formal the start of an organization, institution, or programme:
examples: ▪ within a few years of its inception, the charity was involved in aid projects all around the world.
▪ not long after their inception, the welfare programs were under attack.

children.name: to start a new business or organization
start/start up b2
children.definition: start/start up/stɑːʳt, ˌstɑːʳt ˈʌp/  to start a new business or organization: khởi nghiệp
examples: ▪ luigi’s family came here in 1966 and started up a chain of restaurants.
▪ john decided to start his own textile business shortly after the war.
startverbbegin bắt đầu
[ i or t ] (alsostart up) if a business or other organization starts, or if someone starts one, it is created and starts to operate
_she started her own software company.
_a lot of new restaurants have started up in the region.
start (sth) upphrasal verbbusiness bắt đầu hoạt động; đi vào hoạt động
if a business or other organization starts up, or if someone starts one up, it is created and starts to operate
_many small businesses started up in the 1980s to cater to this growing market.
_we ought to start up a drama group.

children.name: open
children.definition: /ˈəʊpən/  to start a business that provides services to the public, such as a shop, restaurant, or hotel: khai trương
examples: ▪ they just opened a new supermarket on van nuys boulevard
.▪ the rail company plans to open several new lines over the next five years.

children.name: set sth up b1
children.definition: set up /ˌset ˈʌp/  to start a new business by making all the necessary arrangements, buying equipment etc: thiết lập
examples: ▪ kate and her partner are setting up their own printing business.
set up in businessto start to run your own business thiết lập một doanh nghiệp
▪ the enterprise center runs courses for people who want to set up in business on their own.
set up as thiết lập, khởi nghiệp như
▪ dad set up as a builder in 1990 and now he employs over twenty men.

children.name: establish b2
children.definition: establish/ɪˈstæblɪʃ/  to start an important organization that is intended to be permanent, or that continues for a very long time: xuất bản, thành lập
examples: ▪ the company was established in 1899.
▪ most of the money will be used to establish local industries and mobilize the work-force.
establishverbstart thành lập
[ t often passive ]to start a company or organization that will continue for a long time
_the brewery was established in 1822.
_these methods of working were established in the last century.

children.name: found b2
children.definition: found/faʊnd/  to start an organization, school, hospital etc, especially by providing the money for it - use this especially about something that was started a long time ago: thành lập, sáng lập
examples: ▪ who originally founded the college?
▪ the bank was founded 60 years ago in munich.
foundation /faʊnˈdeɪʃən/ [uncountable noun] sự thành lập
▪ the hospital has served the needs of the local community since its foundation in 1863.
foundverbbegin sáng lập
[ t ] to bring something into existence
_york was founded by the romans in the year 71 ad.
_she left a large sum of money in her will to found a wildlife sanctuary.
_we are planning a dinner to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the company.

children.name: when a company, shop, business fails
fail x
children.definition: fail/feɪl/
examples: thất bại
▪ a large number of businesses failed when interest rates rose.
nhiều doanh nghiệp đã thất bại khi lãi suất tăng.
▪ several thousands of small businesses fail each week.
cứ mỗi tuần lại có hàng nghìn doanh nghiệp nhỏ thất bại.
failverbstop phá sản; vỡ nợ
[ i ] if a business fails, it is unable to continue because of money problems.

children.name: lose money c1
children.definition: lose money/pounds/dollars, etc. thua lỗ
examples: a business that is losing money is spending more money than it is receiving
_banks will lose millions of pounds because of new legislation.

children.name: close (sth) down b2
children.definition: close down/ˌkləʊz ˈdaʊn/  if a shop, factory, or business closes down, it stops making or selling goods:
examples: đóng cửa
▪ if the factory closes down, 600 people will lose their jobs.
nếu nhà máy đóng cửa, 600 người sẽ mất việc.
▪ coal mines are closing down all over the country.
các mỏ than đang đóng cửa trên khắp cả nước.
▪ not long ago, the orchestra was the pride of the city. now it is on the verge of closing down.
cách đây không lâu, dàn nhạc là niềm tự hào của thành phố. còn giờ đây nó đang trên bờ vực đóng cửa.
close(sth)downphrasal verb[ m ] đóng cửa (xí nghiệp)
if a business or organization closes down or someone closes it down, it stops operating
_all the mines in this area were closed down in the 80's.
_our local butcher is closing down.
4 stop operating[ intransitive and transitive ] (alsoclose down) if a company, shop etc closes, or you close it, it stops operating permanentlysyn shut down→closed:
we have reluctantly decided to close the factory.
the shop closed down some time last year.

children.name: go out of business x
children.definition: go out of business/gəʊ ˌaʊt əv ˈbɪzns/  if a company goes out of business, it stops existing because it is no longer making a profit:
examples: phá sản
▪ many small farms are going out of business.
be put/forced out of business
nhiều nông trang nhỏ sắp phá sản.
be forced to go out of business
bị buộc phải phá sản
▪ as the recession hit, many traders were forced out of business.
vì suy thoái diễn ra nên nhiều thương gia bị buộc phải phá sản.

children.name: go under x
children.definition: go under /ˌgəʊ ˈʌndəʳ/  if a business, bank, or company goes under, it fails - used especially in newspapers and business contexts:
examples: thất bại
▪ when the company went under, some of our workers found positions with ford.
khi công ty thất bại, một số công nhân của chúng tôi đã tìm được vị trí mới ở ford.
go underphrasal verbfail
if a company goes under, it fails financially
_the charity will go under unless a generous donor can be found within the next few months.
go underinformal
if a company goes under, it is unsuccessful and has to stop doing business
_thousands of companies went under during the recession.

children.name: go bankrupt c1/go bust x
children.definition: go bankrupt/go bust/ˌgəʊ ˈbæŋkrʌpt, ˌgəʊ ˈbʌst/  informal if a person or company goes bankrupt, they are legally forced to sell their property and possessions to pay their debts:
examples: phá sản
▪ her father went bankrupt in 1984.
bố cô phá sản vào năm 1984.
▪ he bought a small printing firm that had gone bankrupt.
anh ta mua một hãng in nhỏ đã phá sản.
▪ the company went bust last year, owing £12 million.
năm ngoái, công ty đã phá sản, nợ 12 triệu bảng.
go bust phá sản, vỡ nợ
if a company goes bust, it is forced to close because it is financially unsuccessful.
_more than twenty companies in the district went bust during the last three months.

children.name: fold x
children.definition: fold/fəʊld/ informalto fail and be unable to continue in business:
examples: thất bại
▪ most of the companies dependent on the steelworks folded within weeks.
nhiều công ty phụ thuộc vào các nhà máy thépđã phá sản chỉ trong vài tuần.
foldverbfailphá sản; vỡ nợ
[ i ] (of a business) to close because of failure
_many small businesses fold within the first year.

children.name: go to the wall x
children.definition: go to the wall/ˌgəʊ tə ðə ˈwɔːl/  informal to fail and be unable to continue in business, especially because of difficult economic conditions:
examples: lâm vào bế tắc
▪ over 300 small firms have gone to the wall in the past year.
hơn 300 doanh nghiệp nhỏ đã lâm vào bế tắc trong năm qua.
▪ high interest rates will force many businesses to go to the wall.
lãi suất cao sẽ làm nhiều doanh nghiệp lâm vào bế tắc.
go to the wall
if a company goes to the wall it is destroyed financially
_after nine months of massive losses the company finally went to the wall.

children.name: crash c1
children.definition: crashverbfail
examples: [ i ] if something such as a business crashes, it suddenly fails or becomes unsuccessful
_investors were seriously worried when the stock market began to crash.

children.name: collapse c2
children.definition: collapseverbfail suy sụp; sụp đổ
examples: [ i ] (of people and business) to suddenly be unable to continue or work correctly
_lots of people lost their jobs when the property market collapsed.
_talks between management and unions have collapsed.
_share prices collapsed (= became lower suddenly) after news of poor trading.

children.name: venture c2
children.definition: venture/ˈventʃəʳ/  a new business activity which involves risking money:
examples: ▪ the group is planning to risk everything to get their next venture off the ground.
business venture
▪ his bankruptcy was the result of several reckless business ventures.
joint venture
▪ ford has invested $125 million in a joint venture to build engines in china.
venturenoun[ c ] việc mạo hiểm, việc liều lĩnh
a new activity, usually in business, which involves risk oruncertainty
_she advised us to look abroad for more lucrativebusinessventures.
_there are manyjointventures between american and japanese companies.

children.name: liquidate x
children.definition: liquidateverbclose thanh lý
examples: [ i or t ] to cause a business to close, so that itsassetscan be sold to pay its debts
liquidationnoun[ c or u ] sựthanh lý
_after three years of heavy losses the companywent intoliquidation with debts totalling £100 million.
liquidatornoun[ c ] người thanh lý
one of the people in charge of closing a company

children.name: branch out
children.definition: phrasal verb đa dạng hoá; mở rộng; toả nhánh
examples: to start to do something different from what you usually do, especially in your job
_this designer has recently branched outintochildren's wear.
_after a couple of years working for other people, she branched outonherown(= started her own business) .

children.name: prosper x
children.definition: prosperverb thịnh vượng; phồn vinh; thành công; phát đạt
examples: (of a person or a business) to be or become successful, especially financially
_a lot of microchip manufacturing companies prospered at that time.

children.name: diversify x
children.definition: diversifyverb đa dạng hoá; tăng thêm chủng loại hàng hoá
examples: [ i or t ] if a business diversifies, it starts making new products or offering newservices
_many wheat farmers have begun to diversifyintoother forms of agriculture.

children.name: float
children.definition: verbbusiness phát hành cổ phiếu
examples: [ t ] to start sellingsharesin a business or company for the first time
flotation,uk alsofloatationnounbusiness phát hành cổ phiếulần đầu
[ c or u ] when a company'ssharesare sold to the public for the first time
_the glasgow-based company is to launch astock-marketflotation this summer.

children.name: when a new business or organization is start
foundation c1
children.definition: foundationnounbegin sựthành lập; sựsáng lập; (sự)thiết lập
examples: [ u ] when an organization, state, etc. is established
_the foundation of a new state

children.name: establishment c1
children.definition: establishment sự thành lập
examples: ▪ the establishment of nato in 1949 gave the us a leading role in the defence of europe.
establishmentnounstart (sự) thành lập; (sự) thiết lập
[ u ] the process of starting or creating something, for example an organization
_since its establishment two years ago, the advice centre has seen over 500 people a week.
_the establishmentofnew areas of employment is a priority.

children.name: inception x
children.definition: inception/ɪnˈsepʃən/ formalthe start of an organization, institution, or programme
examples: sự thành lập:
▪ within a few years of its inception, the charity was involved in aid projects all around the world.
▪ not long after their inception, the welfare programs were under attack.

children.name: bankrupt x
children.definition: bankruptverblegal làmaivỡ nợ phá sản
examples: to cause someone to become bankrupt
_they feared that the loss would bankrupt them.

children.name: bankruptcy x
children.definition: bankruptcynounlegal sự vỡ nợ; sự phá sản
examples: [ c or u ] a situation in which a business or a person becomes bankrupt
_the company was forced into bankruptcy.
_the toll of bankruptcies was rising daily.

children.name: failure x
children.definition: failure/ˈfeɪljəʳ/
examples: sự thất bại
▪ company failures have led to massive job losses.
thất bại của công ty đã dẫn đến mất việc làm hàng loạt.

children.name: closure c2
children.definition: closurebritish /closingamerican /ˈkləʊʒəʳ, ˈkləʊzɪŋ/  when a shop, factory, or business fails and closes:
examples: sự đóng cửa
▪ further factory closures have been announced.
thông báo đóng cửa nhà máy đã được thông báo thêm.
closure of
sự đóng cửa của
▪ the closing of the minton savings and loan was a great loss to the town
việc đóng cửa minton savings and loan là một mất mát lớn đối với thị trấn..
face/be threatened with closureto be going to close down
đối mặt/ bị đe dọa đóng cửa
▪ penrhyn is now the largest quarry in the world, yet 5 years ago it faced closure.
penrhyn hiện đang là mỏ đá lớn nhất thế giới, nhưng 5 năm trước, nó đã phải đóng cửa.
closurenoun đóng cửa
[ c ] when a business, organization, etc. stops operating
_factory/branch closures
_the unions fought hard against the government's programme of pit closures.
